entry.title: 90 Day Accountability Challenge -- Join Me!

media:group.media:title: 90 Day Accountability Challenge -- Join Me!
media:group.media:description:
This was something I decided to do on impulse (yay ADHD!) but thought could be really fun and helpful. It's based on the concept of no zero days (http://bit.ly/no0days) -- even if we don't have time to do much, doing *something* toward our goals every day can help us get into the habits that support our progress in the areas that are important to us. #challenge #progress
PRINTABLE STICKER CHART to help us remember to do something every day: http://bit.ly/90dayskillchallenge
EMAIL TO SEND VIDEOS TO: Progress@HowtoADHD.com
DEADLINE: To be included in the video -- email FIRST video by Monday, September 21st, 2020; submit FINAL video by December 21st, 2020, at midnight PST.
INSTRUCTIONS: 1. Record a video of you performing a skill you want to improve 2. Send the video to: Progress@HowtoADHD.com (by September 21st) 3. Practice that skill every day for 90 days (printable sticker chart to help you keep track: http://bit.ly/90dayskillchallenge ) 4. Record another video after 90 days to show your progress and send that video to: Progress@HowtoADHD.com (by December 21st)
FAQ: Q: I missed a day. Can I still submit a video? A: Yeah! The goal is to have no zero days, meaning to do at least a *little* every day, but hi we have ADHD. Try to get 90 days in but if you miss a few days just let us know in the final video how many days you practiced :)
Q: I saw this vlog after the first deadline or forgot to do it in time. Can I still submit a video? A: Yeah! If this is helpful for people we may do it again, so go ahead and start whenever. The deadlines are just to be included in the video we're making for the end of the year.
Q: I have a question about this challenge that isn't answered here. Uh.... A: use # FAQ and ask your question. If it's appropriate for the FAQ, I'll add it when I see it :) -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

entry.title: How to Deal with Rejection Sensitivity

media:group.media:title: How to Deal with Rejection Sensitivity
media:group.media:description:
This is my most requested episode ever. Thanks to the support of my research team, creative team, professional consultants, and the fabulous Caroline Maguire, it's finally done :) Enjoy!!! FREE PRINTABLE REFERENCE CARD: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oncdgtsFqd1jWrkqAjqD9xCjT9SQk0_n/view?usp=sharing (it fits great in a bullet journal, or fold it to stick in a wallet!)
CHECK OUT DANI'S COGNITIVE DISTORTIONS: https://www.adhddd.com/shop/the-faces-of-cognitive-distortions/
GET CAROLINE'S BOOK: https://www.carolinemaguireauthor.com/
Caroline Maguire, M.Ed., ACCG, PCC founded and facilitates a comprehensive SEL training methodology (#ConnectionMatters) for adults, parents, clinicians and academic professionals on how to develop critical social, emotional and behavioral skills, in themselves and in others. Caroline‚Äôs book Why Will No One Play With Me? is a playbook that includes foolproof scripts on how to communicate ‚Äì with anyone, in any situation ‚Äì and how to ensure the message registers with the recipient ‚Äì no small task! Through her private practice, publications, lectures and workshops, her mission is to vanquish the devastating effects of feeling different and misunderstood.

entry.title: What It's Like to Be ADHD and Black

media:group.media:title: What It's Like to Be ADHD and Black
media:group.media:description:
There are many factors that affect our lived experience of ADHD. This is the first in a series of videos that will explore what it's like to be ADHD *and.* Given what's going on in this country, I thought it was important to start with what it's like to be ADHD and Black.
00:00 Intro 01:57 Meet The Brains 05:42 Mental Health And The Black Community 10:00 Masking and Code-Switching 12:32 Dealing With Discrimination 19:09 Moving Forward 24:04 Outro 25:03 Endcard

entry.title: ADHD and Boredom

media:group.media:title: ADHD and Boredom
media:group.media:description:
Hello brains! Being stuck at home during a global pandemic, there's a good chance we're getting bored...and when we get bored, we don't always make the best choices. Here's a simple mindfulness tool that can help.
#stayhome
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd
CONSULTANTS FOR THIS VIDEO: Patrick A. LaCount, PhD Eric Tivers, LCSW Raffael Boccamazzo, PsyD ("Dr. B") Vitea "V" Medici
V. also made a list of *all* the sources that were used while making this video and we‚Äôll try to keep this up for all future videos as well!
DISCLAIMER: The inclusion of a source does not equal agreement with everything that source does. The list provided below consists of *all* sources that were read/consulted to research and make this video.
STUDIES:
Blum, K., Chen, A. L., Braverman, E. R., Comings, D. E., Chen, T. J., Arcuri, V., Blum, S. H., Downs, B. W., Waite, R. L., Notaro, A., Lubar, J., Williams, L., Prihoda, T. J., Palomo, T., & Oscar-Berman, M. (2008). Attention-deficit-hyperactivity disorder and reward deficiency syndrome. Neuropsychiatric disease and treatment, 4(5), 893‚Äì918. https://doi.org/10.2147/ndt.s2627
Hunter, A., Eastwood, J.D. Does state boredom cause failures of attention? Examining the relations between trait boredom, state boredom, and sustained attention. Exp Brain Res 236, 2483‚Äì2492 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00221-016-4749-7
Malkovsky, E., Merrifield, C., Goldberg, Y. et al. Exploring the relationship between boredom and sustained attention. Exp Brain Res 221, 59‚Äì67 (2012). https://doi.org/10.1007/s00221-012-3147-z
Barnes, J. J., Dean, A. J., Nandam, L. S., Oconnell, R. G., & Bellgrove, M. A. (2011). The Molecular Genetics of Executive Function: Role of Monoamine System Genes. Biological Psychiatry, 69(12). https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biopsych.2010.12.040
ARTICLES: https://www.verywellmind.com/adhd-and-boredom-20493 http://cogbtherapy.com/mindfulness-meditation-blog/mindfulness-stop-skill https://www.additudemag.com/boredom-at-work-with-adhd/ https://psychcentral.com/blog/adhd-and-adults-helpful-tips-for-beating-boredom/ https://www.amenclinics.com/blog/boredom-in-adhd/ https://www.additudemag.com/inside-the-add-mind/
BOOKS: Mann, S. (2016). The Science of Boredom: Why Boredom is Good. London: Robinson.
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

entry.title: How to Make a Stay at Home Plan During the Crisis

media:group.media:title: How to Make a Stay at Home Plan During the Crisis
media:group.media:description:
Parents! A lot of you have expressed having a hard time transitioning to working from home while also trying to homeschool your kids. I've been listening to your questions and brought them to Brendan Mahan, M.Ed, M.S. of ADHD Essentials. http://ADHDessentials.com
Here, he talks about how to create a stay-at-home plan that actually works. I think it's actually a useful way to plan in general when you have ADHD!
THE PDF: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gviz3PoANMHcESFohJpJ-N1mlTKwGEFp0jGE3p07JmA/edit?usp=sharing

entry.title: ADHD and Motivation

media:group.media:title: ADHD and Motivation
media:group.media:description:
Hello Brains! Having trouble Doing the Thing? You're not alone. Motivation is one of the biggest challenges most ADHDers face. This episode is all about how to fix Motivation Bridge.
Special thanks to Doctor B from TakeThis.org for coming up with the clever phrase "fill in the planks" -- and for motivating me in so many ways.
And of course, a giant thank you to my brilliant editors and animators Palestrina and JustCallMeGary for working tirelessly to help me bring Motivation Bridge to life (and making me cry). You should...you should sleep now.

entry.title: What ‚ÄúInto the Woods‚Äù Taught Me About Change

media:group.media:title: What ‚ÄúInto the Woods‚Äù Taught Me About Change
media:group.media:description:
Hello Brains! This is a vlog style video, I wanted to get a bit more intimate than usual and talk about how I'm doing personally as well as share some things I learned from "Into the Woods" about how to deal with change, loss, and the grief that comes with it. It was really helpful for me, hope it helps you too. ‚ô•Ô∏è
****If you're in crisis, text CONNECT to 741741****
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd
WE WROTE A SONG!! Get the ‚ÄúThe Fish Song‚Äù on... ...iTunes: http://bit.ly/fishsongitunes ...Google Music: http://bit.ly/fishsonggp ...Amazon: http://bit.ly/fishsongamazon
LINKS:
Grief vs. Depression: https://www.verywellmind.com/grief-and-depression-1067237
Excerpt from the video:
"When something big changes, there‚Äôs this desire to figure out why it happened and whose fault it is, and retracing your steps and their steps and placing blame but the truth is it‚Äôs never one person‚Äôs fault, it‚Äôs always a joint effort
and the fact is no matter how you ended up here, you‚Äôre here --
and suddenly the way isn‚Äôt clear, the light isn‚Äôt good, and none of the paths look familiar.
Suddenly the story you‚Äôre in doesn‚Äôt make sense.
The narrator is gone.
And you find yourself lost in the woods with no way back to the life you knew.
When this happens, you might be angry ‚Äî at other people, at yourself, at the woods ‚Äî
you might try to bargain with them, you might try to pretend everything‚Äôs fine and nothing has changed,
you might want to give up and leave the woods entirely.
You might feel like you‚Äôre not cut out to handle any of this and have no idea how you‚Äôre going to make it through.
That‚Äôs grief.
And that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve been dealing with.
Accepting that my life isn‚Äôt the same anymore has been really challenging for me.
Letting go of what I had, what I would have had.
Starting over when I thought I‚Äôd never have to again. Even though I chose to leave, I didn‚Äôt choose the reasons I felt I had to.
And dealing with this grief has brought up a lot of past grief, a lot of loss,
my grandparents, my dad, important people that have guided me in the past and aren‚Äôt around to anymore.
Sometimes my grief feels like it might be slipping into depression, because I feel useless and there‚Äôs a part of me that doesn‚Äôt care, that doesn‚Äôt see how getting through the woods even matters, because I‚Äôve lost the thread of why I‚Äôm even here, what my place is in this story.
A few takeaways that I really love from Into the Woods though were this ‚Äî
1. No one is alone, and even those who aren‚Äôt around anymore can still guide us
2. Even when things don‚Äôt go the way we want, we learn things, we gain resources. We‚Äôre never really starting over.
3. And when we have no idea where to start and we‚Äôre daunted by it all to the point that we‚Äôre ready to give up, we can start with the small actions we can take.
The father left alone to raise a child could start with ‚Äúcalm the child.‚Äù
I can start with ‚Äútalk about grief.‚Äù
It‚Äôs going to take me time to make sense of my life again.
And after the emotional earthquake I‚Äôve gone through I can‚Äôt move through the woods as quickly as I‚Äôm used to, which is really frustrating.
But there are actions I can take.
It isn‚Äôt hopeless.
I can‚Äôt have the life I knew, but I can build a new one.
It won‚Äôt be the same, but it doesn‚Äôt have to be the same to be good.
And while the woods aren‚Äôt as friendly a place for me as they used to be, I don‚Äôt have to face them alone.
None of us do.
Thank you, Brains.
What "Into the Woods" Taught Me About Change

entry.title: How to Do The Thing! A Pep Talk! ...no. SONG!

media:group.media:title: How to Do The Thing! A Pep Talk! ...no. SONG!
media:group.media:description:
Hello Brains!
Okay, so, appaaaarently it wasn't enough to just WRITE the song...I also had to learn it, record it, shoot like 68 scenes of me doing things you said you'd do...3 weeks later, ENJOY!!! Hope you like it! (If it gets annoying, you can turn it off as soon as you do the thing ;) )
Capo 3
G Hello Brains! For this New Year D I wrote a silly song for you Em To encourage and annoy you into D Doing things you said you‚Äôd do
‚Äî 150 BPM G Brush your hair, make your bed D Get a job that you don‚Äôt hate Em Practice cursive every day Bm D Don‚Äôt forget to meditate
G Actually get out of bed D and be less self deprecating A Use a pomodoro timer D Spend 5 hours animating
G Say some mantras, do some pull-ups D Exercise your chest and core Em Be more honest ‚Äòbout your feelings Bm D Take yourself to movies more
G Only eat out once a month D Write 3 pages every day A Get to sleep before midnight D Play piano on Tuesdays
‚Äî
Bridge:
G Goals can be intimidating Am D Falling short can be frustrating A But here‚Äôs a simple Brain-proof method D D7 That I‚Äôll share with you
‚Äî CHORUS:
Super cheery, 170 BPM G Do it badly D Do it terribly C D Write 3 pages that no one would read G D You have so many reasons to do these things A D And none of you said you‚Äôd do them perfectlyyyyy
So --
G Get a ukulele, play it, D Use your planner every day Em Dance like no one‚Äôs watching you Bm D Do your laundry every Sunday (alt: on Sundays) Opt:Read your bible, keep the faith G Pack your bag and pick out clothes D The night before so you‚Äôre not late A Exercise 3 days a week D Sing cause it makes choir way‚Ä¶ Easier‚Ä¶
G Practice oboe, do your push-ups D Brush your teeth and wash your face Em Ignore your phone until you‚Äôre ready Bm D So you don‚Äôt procrastinate
G Drink some water, take a selfie D And do not forget to eat A Wash the dishes every night D Program at least twice a week
And G Do it badly D Do it terribly C D Take a selfie that no one will see G D You have so many reasons to do these things A D Way more important than doing them perfectlyyyyy
So
G Stick to the routines you‚Äôve built; D Reach out to friends and family Em Write a little every day. Bm D So you‚Äôll finish that book, Leigh!
G Work before your boyfriend gets home D Take an hour just for you A Pray and read devotionals D walk 10 minutes, hula hoop
G Do your homework after school and D Get rid of toxicity. Em Adventure every Thursday so you Bm D Don‚Äôt resent all your routines ‚Äî
G Take your meds, draw before bed D Walk up 8 whole flights of stairs A Daily coding challenges and D Be more present with your kids
And G Do it badly D Do it terribly C D Code a solution that won‚Äôt work gen‚Äôrally G D You have so many reasons to do these things A D And seriously, please don‚Äôt do them perfectly ‚Äî You‚Äôll make the rest of us look really bad and we don‚Äôt like that ‚Äî
CODA? SECOND BRIDGE?: G I understand perfectionism Am D I even made this video A But sometimes being perfect can mean D Just doing it at all G So if you want to ever be good Am D Don‚Äôt let perfect get in your way A Make lots of pots Like Hank Green D And you know someday
G It won‚Äôt be badly D Might not be perfectly, C D But you‚Äôll write something that someone will read G D You have so many reasons to do these things A D And next year you‚Äôll be proud of you, just wait and see ‚Äî
If you
G Journal, tap dance, walk your dog D More often, study Arabic Em French or Japanese, Italian Bm D Write down your accomplishments
G Put your phone down after work D Go outside, eat a vegetable A Practice watercolor painting D Don‚Äôt end all your texts with ‚ÄúLOL‚Äù
G Start your projects when you get them D Tweet and post on Instagram Em Buy a wig and wear it daily Bm D -- stick to your study plans
G Find accountabili-buddies D Be creative every day A Start your blog or YouTube channel and D Iiiii‚Äôll be here to say‚Ä¶(?)
G Do it badly D Do it terribly C Write a song for your viewers -- And mess it up entirely G D You‚Äôve got so many reasons to do these things A D And don‚Äôt worry, cause there‚Äôs no such thing as perfectly ‚Äî G Just done.

entry.title: Am I Lazy, Stupid, Messy, Flaky? ADHD

media:group.media:title: Am I Lazy, Stupid, Messy, Flaky? ADHD
media:group.media:description:
Hello brains and hearts!
ADHD can be challenging enough, but the stigma surrounding it can sometimes be worse. We're labeled "lazy," "stupid," "messy," "flaky," and a lot more -¬†sometimes by people we respect. Sometimes we label ourselves. What it all comes down to is "shame."
When everyone around you is doubting you, it's really hard not to doubt yourself. Here's how to cope.
(spoiler: sometimes one of the best tools we have is each other)

entry.title: How to (Actually) Help Someone Who's Depressed

media:group.media:title: How to (Actually) Help Someone Who's Depressed
media:group.media:description:
It can be hard to watch someone you care about struggle with depression, especially when nothing you say seems to make a difference. Here's how to (actually) help.
Connect with us: Facebook: facebook.com/howtoadhd Twitter: twitter.com/howtoadhd Forums: howtoadhd.com/forums Support us on Patreon: patreon.com/howtoadhd
People who take their lives don't want to die‚Äîthey just want to stop hurting.
How to help:
https://www.helpguide.org/articles/suicide-prevention/suicide-prevention.htm How to be a friend: http://www.takethis.org/expert-advice/how-to-be-a-friend/ Preventing suicide: https://www.nami.org/Find-Support/Family-Members-and-Caregivers/Preventing-Suicide https://thebestschools.org/magazine/vigilant-against-teen-suicide/ https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/suicide-prevention/warning-signs.html
If you have a friend or family member that's been dealing with depression and you suddenly see an upswing in their mood, pay close attention. Signs of suicide are an abrupt sense of calm, giving gifts and personal possessions (especially valuable items or items of personal significance/sentimental value).
The most important thing you can do if you're feeling suicidal is to tell someone. These numbers are free, confidential and avail 24/7: Call: 800-273-TALK (8255) Text: HOME to 741741
International numbers: http://suicide.org/international-suicide-hotlines.html
LINKS:
Take This: http://www.takethis.org/expert-advice/what-is-depression/ Doctor B: http://twitter.com/theedoctorb

entry.title: Why I'm Upset at Netflix's New Documentary "Take Your Pills"

media:group.media:title: Why I'm Upset at Netflix's New Documentary "Take Your Pills"
media:group.media:description:
Controversy sells, and the media knows it. So a lot of what we see, read about, and hear about ADHD and ADHD treatment either misrepresents the facts or is flat-out meant to scare us.
Netflix's new documentary "Take Your Pills" (interview w/producers: https://youtu.be/L-cq_HKdQwc) is no exception. This is why I'm upset: Despite bringing up many legitimate concerns, the film contributes to the confusion, stigma and fear around stimulant medication ‚Äî many of the experts included either don‚Äôt have a background in research, directly benefit from spreading fear & misinformation about ADHD treatment, or speak on subjects outside their area of expertise.
This is a problem, because ‚Äî as this study found (https://www.liebertpub.com/doi/abs/10.1089/cap.2012.0087) ‚Äî ‚ÄúInaccurate and sensationalized media reports surrounding ADHD and its treatments [have] a major impact on parental decision making‚Äù when it comes to treatment.
Fortunately, a TON of research has been done on stimulant medications, so you and your doctor can decide what‚Äôs right for you or your child based on facts, not fear.
This is Dr. Hallowell‚Äôs full response to ‚ÄúTake Your Pills:‚Äù https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V6hhH8zkFfM&feature=youtu.be Dr. Hallowell is a psychiatrist and leading ADHD expert who‚Äôs written over 20 books on ADHD, including ‚ÄúDriven to Distraction‚Äù and ‚ÄúDelivered From Distraction‚Äù and is finishing up his memoir, which you can pre-order here: http://www.drhallowell.com/free-sample-chapter-dr-hallowells-memoir/
Remember, documentaries aren‚Äôt peer-reviewed. And not all research studies are created equal.
Here‚Äôs a guide to understanding research studies: http://www.chadd.org/Understanding-ADHD/About-ADHD/The-Science-of-ADHD/Understanding-Research-Studies.aspx
Here are some reliable sources of information about ADHD and ADHD treatment: ADHD facts: https://add.org/adhd-facts/ What we know about the long-term effects of ADHD medication: https://childmind.org/article/know-long-term-effects-adhd-medications/ Why dosage matters: https://childmind.org/article/is-your-child-getting-the-right-medication-dose/ Types of ADHD medication: https://www.understood.org/en/learning-attention-issues/treatments-approaches/medications/types-of-adhd-medications Why stimulants help ADHD (Sci Show, includes research): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoX0vEDn5a4&feature=youtu.be ‚ÄúGetting Ahead of ADHD‚Äù by Dr. Joel T. Nigg (fantastic book on treating childhood ADHD, includes non-medication options & talks about meds starting p224): https://www.amazon.com/Getting-Ahead-ADHD-Next-Generation-Treatments/dp/1462524931/ref=mt_paperback?_encoding=UTF8&me= The difference between the effect of amphetamines & methamphetamines: http://www.jbc.org/content/284/5/2978.full.pdf What actually causes addiction? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ao8L-0nSYzg And here is a systematic review that includes 69 recent (2011-2016) studies related to ADHD treatment: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0098860/
Citations:
Kemper, A. R., Maslow, G. R., Hill, S., Namdari, B., Allen LaPointe, N. M., Goode, A. P., ‚Ä¶ Sanders, G. D. (2018). Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder: Diagnosis and Treatment in Children and Adolescents. Rockville (MD): Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (US). Retrieved from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK487761/
Clavenna, A., & Bonati, M. (2017). Pediatric pharmacoepidemiology - safety and effectiveness of medicines for ADHD. Expert Opinion on Drug Safety, 16(12), 1335‚Äì1345. https://doi.org/10.1080/14740338.2017.1389894
Merkel, R. L., & Kuchibhatla, A. (2009). Safety of stimulant treatment in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: Part I. Expert Opinion on Drug Safety, 8(6), 655‚Äì668. https://doi.org/10.1517/14740330903279956
Merkel, R. L. (2010). Safety of stimulant treatment in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: part II. Expert Opinion on Drug Safety, 9(6), 917‚Äì935. https://doi.org/10.1517/14740338.2010.503238
Swanson, J. M., Arnold, L. E., Molina, B. S., Sibley, M. H., Hechtman, L. T., Hinshaw, S. P., Abikoff, H. B., Stehli, A. , Owens, E. B., Mitchell, J. T., Nichols, Q. , Howard, A. , Greenhill, L. L., Hoza, B. , Newcorn, J. H., Jensen, P. S., Vitiello, B. , Wigal, T. , Epstein, J. N., Tamm, L. , Lakes, K. D., Waxmonsky, J. , Lerner, M. , Etcovitch, J. , Murray, D. W., Muenke, M. , Acosta, M. T., Arcos‚ÄêBurgos, M. , Pelham, W. E., Kraemer, H. C., , , Severe, J. B., Richters, J. , Vereen, D. , Elliott, G. R., Wells, K. C., Conners, C. K., March, J. , Cantwell, D. P., Gibbons, R. D., Marcus, S. , Hur, K. , Hanley, T. and Stern, K. entry.title: 5 Ways Dogs Help ADHD Brains -- in 360 Degrees!!!

media:group.media:title: 5 Ways Dogs Help ADHD Brains -- in 360 Degrees!!!
media:group.media:description:
Link to last video on the terretorio de zaguates: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gsew6RhXhMw
Dogs can be wonderful for ADHD brains!
But a lot of these benefits depend on you having a good relationship with your dog, so make sure you choose one that‚Äôs right for you and your family. Do as much research ahead of time as possible and make sure you meet your new family member in person before you commit!
http://www.akc.org/find-a-match/#slide1
http://www.animalplanet.com/breed-selector/dog-breeds/questionnaire/page1.html
picking a puppy (VIDEO): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J9khrqxVpAc
picking a shelter dog (article): http://3lostdogs.com/a-guide-to-choosing-the-right-dog-from-a-shelter/
WARNING: There are many ‚Äúregistries‚Äù that are essentially scams. You do NOT need to register your emotional support animal, or have a vest or ID card for them. All you need is a letter from your doctor or therapist explaining why you need one.
For service animals, which autistic people often benefit from, you do not need a vest either, although many handlers choose to use one. What makes a service dog a service dog is the specialized training they go through to provide a specific task or tasks to assist with their handler‚Äôs disability and be able to behave in public places.
More on service dog scams: http://servicedogcentral.org/content/fake-service-dog-credentials
Right to Emotional Support Animals in "No Pet‚Äù Housing:
http://www.bazelon.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/2017-06-16-Emotional-Support-Animal-Fact-Sheet-for-Website-final.pdf
More on emotional support animals: http://www.akc.org/content/entertainment/articles/everything-about-emotional-support-animals/
Link to Fair Housing Act: https://www.hud.gov/sites/documents/SERVANIMALS_NTCFHEO2013-01.PDF
Laws in other countries: https://assistancedogsinternational.org/access-and-laws/adi-guide-to-assistance-dog-laws/
Canada (opinion piece, provides links): http://helpmentalhealth.squarespace.com/canadian-laws/
What‚Äôs The Difference Between a Service Dog, Therapy Dog, and an Emotional Support Animal? (VIDEO) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4C459sQwrAo&feature=youtu.be
More about service dogs: https://www.huffingtonpost.com/janice-celeste/service-dogs-not-allowed-_b_8062976.html
What NOT to do around service dogs (video by Drew Lynch): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U9PqaaIBjq0
Find an assistance dog!
International: https://www.assistancedogsinternational.org/
Canada: http://www.cagads.com/programs.html

entry.title: What Happened With Patreon (Vlog Update)

entry.title: How to ADHD Merch is Finally Here!!!!!!!!!

media:group.media:title: How to ADHD Merch is Finally Here!!!!!!!!!
media:group.media:description:
Hello Brains and Hearts! If you've been wondering where I've been -- now you know! Edward and I have been in our secret workshop making How to ADHD merch, aaand we may have gotten a bit carried away (ALL THE THINGS!):
https://howtoadhd.com/shop
The site is a bit confusing at first but is awesome once you get the hang of it.
Here's the deal: click on the link then click on "shop." That will show you a sampling of cool products and give you the ability to search by department (men's, women's, stationary, etc.) or by product "show me stickers!"
Orrrrr you can click on "portfolio" and view the different "collections." "Collections" is their fancy way of saying designs. In the portfolio, you can click on whatever design you're interested in and then below that it will show you all the stuff you can get that design printed on :D
You can also get a 10% off your full first order if you join their mailing list!

entry.title: 3 Ways to Be Grateful (That Don't Involve Gratitude Lists)

media:group.media:title: 3 Ways to Be Grateful (That Don't Involve Gratitude Lists)
media:group.media:description:
Happy Thanksgiving!!
I've tried to make gratitude lists a bunch of times, but they always end up making me feel more stressed out (or pressured to feel grateful) than actually grateful. I always thought I was weird and probably should not admit that so people wouldn't assume I'm a horrible, ungrateful person -- but then I realized -- I'm really not! I'm actually pretty happy! Turns out, there are lots of ways to be grateful and happy about your life. Here are a few I use and love!
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

media:group.media:title: Why I'm Grateful to You (Thank You!!!)
media:group.media:description:
Hello Brains and Hearts!
Today is Thanksgiving where I live, so I created an episode on 3 ways to be grateful (that don't involve gratitude lists). It's...not ready quite yet, so it will be up later today, but one of the ways was to write thank-you notes, so this is my thank you note -- to you. This is why I'm grateful to all of you for sharing, commenting, subscribing, subtitling, volunteering, and supporting this show in all the ways you do.
**spoilers**
I'm posting this one first because I'm about to head in to work (yeahhh, servers have to work on holidays) and do something I've been working toward for a very long time, and I wanted to connect with you and thank you before I do.

entry.title: This is What It's Really Like to Have ADHD

media:group.media:title: This is What It's Really Like to Have ADHD
media:group.media:description:
My recent TED Talk got picked up on Facebook and renamed "This is is what it's really like to have ADHD," but that was just my story. ADHD isn't just one story ‚Äì¬†it's the stories of thousands of people around the world. It's the stories of children, of college students, of adult adhd. It's more than their symptoms: it's the story of their struggles and their successes.
These are some of those stories.
If this message means something to you, please share.
If you'd like to know more, please visit: http://howtoadhd.com/howtohelp

entry.title: How to Get Projects Done, On Time, Without Your Life Falling Apart in the Process

media:group.media:title: How to Get Projects Done, On Time, Without Your Life Falling Apart in the Process
media:group.media:description:
One of the biggest challenges ADHD brains face is project management -- in the past I've always tried harder, worked faster, stuffed more into my schedule.
But maybe there's a better way -- deciding which projects aren't even worth taking on in the first place.
This video is meant to help us get projects done, on time, without the rest of your life falling apart in the process.
Special thanks to research consultant Patrick LaCount

entry.title: How to ADHD with Special Guest Dr. Hallowell!!!!

media:group.media:description:
This week, How to ADHD presents an incredible special guest -- Dr. Ned Hallowell!
Dr. Hallowell is a very busy man -- not only a leading ADHD expert, but a New York Times bestselling author who's written 20 books, many of them on ADHD.
But thanks to the generous support from our Patreon Brains, we were able to have someone film him in his New York office while chatted over Skype about living with ADHD, how to deal with the sensitivity to rejection that often comes with it, and the importance of connection.
You all ROCK.

entry.title: How Exercise Can Help with ADHD (and How to Actually Do It)

media:group.media:title: How Exercise Can Help with ADHD (and How to Actually Do It)
media:group.media:description:
Exercise is one of the most-suggested natural treatments for ADHD, and for good reason. Although experts agree that it‚Äôs not usually enough to replace stimulant medication for most people who need it, it does affect the brain in much the same way. Still, exercising regularly can be a challenge for those of us with ADHD -- so I cover some tips that can help!
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd

Attention & Learning Lab: http://uwyoall.com

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5281644/

http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1087054715584053

entry.title: What I Want to Say to My Mom, Who ‚ÄúDrugged‚Äù Me

media:group.media:title: What I Want to Say to My Mom, Who ‚ÄúDrugged‚Äù Me
media:group.media:description:
Whether (or how) to treat a child with ADHD is an understandably tough decision for many parents. My mom decided to, and faced (as many parents do) judgement for her choices. Here‚Äôs what I want to say to her, and every parent who finds themselves accused of ‚Äúdrugging‚Äù their children.
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd
Links to reliable sources of information on ADHD: http://understood.org http://chadd.org http://add.org http://additudemag.com
My video on Zombie ADHD myths & the truth behind them: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V5tLi1bYilA
And if you were one of the people who were hurt or offended by Nicole Arbour‚Äôs video (if not, it‚Äôs not worth watching/giving her views, it‚Äôs just one of her typical misinformed rants), An excellent explanation of why she‚Äôs wrong: https://debunkingdenialism.com/2017/05/08/why-nicole-arbour-is-wrong-about-adhd/
My Little Villagers' response: http://mylittlevillagers.com/2017/04/response-nicole-arbours-video-truth-adhd/
Thank you to my Patreon supporters, for the sake of keeping this video short and shareable I didn't do my usual intro or wrapup, but I could not have done this without all of you.
By the way, in case anyone is curious -- I take Vyvanse now, but I started on Ritalin.
Transcript of video:
What I want to say to my mom, who "drugged" me:
Thank you. Thank you for listening when I told you I was struggling. Thank you for standing up for me when my dad tried to dismiss what I was dealing with as "normal." I now understand ADHD is highly genetic and it's likely he felt that way because he probably had ADHD himself.
Thank you for taking me to get a proper evaluation so I understand my brain's differences and don't feel like it's just all my fault. Thank you for taking me to a psychiatrist, month after month, to find a treatment and dose that worked for me. And for taking me back month after month after month after month -- I know you were busy, and yet I never ran out of medication because you took the time to take me to every appointment.
Thank you for ignoring the people who judged you. I know there were many.
Thank you for understanding that there was a difference between my sister occasionally forgetting her homework and me losing or forgetting something almost every day. Thank you for understanding that while all children can be fidgety or impulsive or get distracted, I struggled way more than the other kids my age. I now understand it's because ADHD brains develop differently.
You didn't know that, you hadn't done the research I have, but you listened to me when I told you I needed help.
Because of you, I got the treatment I needed, I did better in school, I felt more confident and able to reach my potential. Because of you, I never had to self medicate like so many ADHDers I know. I never sank into depression. I never gave up on myself. I never felt misunderstood. You understood. You believed me.
And when you did, when you took me to a doctor who could explain to me what was happening in my brain, you took away so much shame.
Thanks, mom.

entry.title: What Happened When I Stopped Taking My Medication

media:group.media:title: What Happened When I Stopped Taking My Medication
media:group.media:description:
As much as my meds help me, it‚Äôs a battle to remember to do all the things I need to do to be able to take them: sign up for health insurance, pay my bill, make a doctor appointment, GO to that appointment, get my prescription, find a pharmacy that can fill it, remember to pick it up before it closes, remember to bring my ID so they‚Äôll let me...
So when I miss a step and find myself without my meds, it‚Äôs easy to wonder...are they really necessary?
This is what happened when I forgot to pay my health insurance, stopped taking my medication for two weeks and tried to learn how to live without it.
Please share -- because the stigma is real, and no one should have to feel ashamed for getting the treatment they need just because their disorder is mental rather than physical, invisible rather than obvious.
Mental health is just as important as physical health, and it‚Äôs time we acknowledge that.
*NOTE* -- I do not recommend going off medication without a doctor's supervision. A medical professional should be accessible to troubleshoot problems. If you can't reach your doctor, talk to a pharmacist.

American Psychiatric Association. (2015). Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders (5th ed ed.). Washington, DC: Author. Asherson, P., Buitelaar, J., Faraone, S. V., & Rohde, L. A. Moving towards causality in attention-defi cit hyperactivity disorder: overview of neural and genetic mechanisms. Lancet Psychiatry, 3(1), 555-567. Konrad, K., & Eickhoff, S. B. (2010). media:group.media:description:

Progress?

entry.title: How to Build Resilience: Quarters of Encouragement

media:group.media:title: How to Build Resilience: Quarters of Encouragement
media:group.media:description:
The secret to success, especially for those of us with ADHD, seems to be resilience. It doesn't matter how many times we fail, as long as we get back up. There are lots of ways to build resilience, but encouragement is one of the easiest and most powerful. Whether you or your ADHDer are struggling with grade school, friends, relationships, college or career, here are some ways to use "quarters" of encouragement to build the resilience necessary to keep bouncing back.
Facebook: http://facebook.com/howtoadhd Twitter: http://twitter.com/howtoadhd Support us on Patreon: http://patreon.com/howtoadhd
LINKS:
Dr. Hallowell: ‚ÄúHow One Teacher Changed My Life‚Äù http://www.additudemag.com/adhd/article/1605.html Teaching resilience to ADHD children: http://www.additudemag.com/adhd/article/2525.html The right kind of praise: http://www.additudemag.com/adhdblogs/11/9550.html Building Resilience in Children: https://www.healthychildren.org/English/healthy-living/emotional-wellness/Building-Resilience/Pages/Building-Resilience-in-Children.aspx How to Build a Child‚Äôs Self Esteem: http://www.adhdtogether.com/life-skills-with-adhd/how-build-self-esteem For ADHD adults: Silence Your Inner Critic http://www.additudemag.com/adhd/article/9572.html Research paper: Reasons for Success and Implications for Resilience: https://www.deepdyve.com/lp/guilford-press/employment-of-adults-with-learning-disabilities-and-adhd-reasons-for-RpkfBC58Pg?articleList=%2Fsearch%3Fquery%3Dresilience%2Badhd Not just about resilience, but found this and loved it ‚Äî ‚ÄúAdult ADHD: 50 tips of management‚Äù http://www.drhallowell.com/adult-adhd-50-tips-of-management/

entry.title: My 10 Favorite Things About Having ADHD

media:group.media:title: My 10 Favorite Things About Having ADHD
media:group.media:description:
There are many strengths that go along with our ADHD symptoms. Which strengths you have and express will depend on a lot of factors, and it's not the same for everybody, but here are my 10 favorite things about having ADHD that have been true for me, I've found in my research and I see in many other ADHDers too.
Also -- to be clear I am NOT saying ADHD is not a challenge or a legitimate disorder. I am not saying we shouldn't get treatment. I am on Vyvanse myself and a big believer in multimodal treatment so that we can overcome those challenges and enjoy our strengths.

entry.title: ADHD and Friendships: How to Play the Social Game!

media:group.media:title: ADHD and Friendships: How to Play the Social Game!
media:group.media:description:
The way ADHD brains develop can put us out of step with our childhood peers, leaving us feeling awkward, left out and with social anxiety that can follow us into adulthood. Here, I talk about my own experiences with that, and offer simple solutions.
**note -- I want to add that one of the Brains pointed out that peers and the internet aren't always the best source of information, which is true. Cultures vary, biases like racism and sexism exist, and also, well-meaning advice that might work for one person won't necessarily be appropriate for another.
My hope is that we can sift through all the information available to us and check in with ourselves as to whether or not it feels right.
In any case, personally, if I'd known what to expect on a sleepover, how to be a good "host," or what appropriate etiquette is for a first date, I think I would have felt a lot more prepared to deal with the social situations I found myself in.
****LINKS!**** http://bit.ly/2bbAhRp Podcast mentioned in the video ‚Äîgreat info about playdates and more! http://bit.ly/2bc9ckg Help Your Child with ADHD Make Friends http://bit.ly/2aHW5kX Helping girls with ADHD make friends http://bit.ly/2b5KiSE Friendship challenges for adults http://bit.ly/2b3FKew ADHD brains mature a few years late¬†

entry.title: What Do We Do About Hate

media:group.media:title: What Do We Do About Hate
media:group.media:description:
I should have been more clear in the video, when I'm talking about hate I'm talking about hate that results in aggression. And I was embarrassed to realize I'd said "sexual preference" when I meant "sexual orientation." This was an emotional video for me and I stumbled through expressing something I've never put into words. apologies for the mistakes.
The Orlando massacre was devastating, and what devestates me the most is that after every shooting we are horrified and then complacent. Myself included.
I don't know if gun control can solve the problem. I think the puzzle is far more complicated than that.
I don't know exactly what needs to be done.
But I know what I can do.
I love Jimmy Fallon's piece as well: https://www.facebook.com/FallonTonight/videos/10154292540968896/?pnref=story

entry.title: ADHD in Girls: How to Recognize the Symptoms

media:group.media:title: ADHD in Girls: How to Recognize the Symptoms
media:group.media:description:
In this video I highlight the different ways ADHD symptoms tend to express themselves in girls. For a better sense of ADHD in general check out "How to Know if You Have ADHD:" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cx13a2-unjE
To clarify: I am not suggesting that there is a "girl" or a "boy" form of ADHD. Either gender can have the hyperactivity component, and either gender can be primarily inattentive. In this video I talk about what is more common; however, it's important that we learn to recognize both forms in both genders.

entry.title: How to Know if You Have ADHD

media:group.media:title: How to Know if You Have ADHD
media:group.media:description:
I'm not a doctor, but here are some things you need to know.
UPDATE: the three "types" as described by the DSM IV have been updated to be called "presentations" -- inattentive presentation, etc. to better represent the fluidity of symptoms and their ability to change over time.
Test for adult ADHD (from additudemag.com):http://bit.ly/21yRB96 ADHD test designed specifically for women (from additudemag.com): http://bit.ly/1pmtxoz
(video) A really funny, painfully accurate "unofficial test" by Totally ADD: http://bit.ly/1SeF6tj
Recently diagnosed? You might be feeling like this: http://bit.ly/1LS06PU

entry.title: ADHD and Relationships: Let's Be Honest

media:group.media:title: ADHD and Relationships: Let's Be Honest
media:group.media:description:
This week, I address one of the biggest problems in ADHD relationships that no one seems to talk about.
Disclaimer: to be clear, when I talk about the things we do to preserve the dopamine high, I am NOT saying everyone with ADHD does any or all of these. This part of the video is based heavily on my personal experience. Although those of us with ADHD are certainly more prone to boredom and risk-taking behavior, having ADHD is not an indicator of whether or not a person will cheat.
Read more about dopamine! http://www.simplywellbeing.com/under-...
Four things ADHD brains can focus on taken from: Puryear, Douglas A. Your Life Can Be Better, Using Strategies for Adult ADD/ADHD. Mill City Press, Inc. 2012. http://www.amazon.com/Your-Better-Using-Strategies-Adult/dp/1937600432/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1463612451&sr=8-1&keywords=your+life+can+be+better+douglas
